PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Hill representing the Prime Minister. Minister, can you explain on what basis Mr Max Moore-Wilton accepted Philomena Bisshop's resignation? Isn't it the case that she took the initiative in inquiring of DAS whether there had been any cover‐up of repayments of travel allowance by government ministers? Isn't it also the case that when she recalled on 26 September the conference that she had with Carolyn Hughes of DAS in early July, she drew the conversation to the attention of her superior officers without any mention being made of resignation at that stage? Why is it that two days later, on 28 September, her failure to pass her conversation with DAS up the line was dealt with as a hanging offence? Do you agree that this is an appropriate sanction for a public servant in her position?

—As I remember the matter, she chose to resign for what she said was basically a failure to meet the responsibilities of her office. As I recall, what she said was that she acknowledged that she, at the relevant time—which was when she believed that she had the earlier discussion—should have brought the substance of these discussions to the attention of her superiors. As I further recall, she very much regretted that she failed to do so, but certainly acknowledged that that was a failure of her responsibilities within her office. That is basically where the matter rests.

—Surely not quite, Minister. Because doesn't the much more serious offence lie in fact with the Department of Administrative Services? Isn't it clear from the documentation that was tabled yesterday by the Prime Minister that DAS knew of the cover‐up of the repayment of travel allowance by a government minister, knew that this has been decided by Mr Jull, knew that it has been discussed with the Prime Minister's office and acquiesced in it? What are the implications for DAS of the Philomena Bisshop resignation, the Philomena Bisshop precedent? What are the implications for DAS there?

—I do not think there are any implications that follow from the decision that was made by Philomena Bisshop. That was her decision and her interaction was with the superiors within her department. The extent of DAS's knowledge of these matters is an interesting but different question. Certainly, it would seem that at least some officers in DAS were aware of the way in which it had been decided to deal with the correction to Mr Sharp's statement. That is true, but what flows from that is really not within my province.

On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both informative and enjoyable. TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is to Senator Alston, the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, given the small business sector's call for reform across many fronts, will the government distinguish itself from the previous Labor administration and take further action to improve the outlook for Australian small business?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 May this year the House of Representatives handed down a fair trading committee report and a matter of months later the government is now in a position to respond to that report, as Mr Reith will be doing in the House of Representatives later today. That stands in stark contrast to the approach adopted by Labor to small business over very many years. In fact, over a period of 11 years they tabled 17 different reports. If you look at all of those reports—talk about a recipe for inaction—there was a particular contribution by the minister for making businesses smaller, Senator Schacht, who commissioned a couple of working party reports.

ANSWER.PARA: About all they managed to do over that whole period was boost one small business, and that was the printing industry. But apart from that, they were not serious at all. In fact, in the run‐up to the last election they finally proposed into the House of Representatives a better business conduct bill, but of course that lapsed because of the proroguing of the parliament.

It is perfectly clear that Labor had absolutely no interest in the whole issue of small business and that is why it stands in such stark contrast to the actions that Mr Reith will be announcing later today. The government will be outlawing unconscionable conduct against small business, strengthening the protection for retail tenants and giving full effect to industry codes of practice.

Where does the Labor Party stand on all these issues? The fact is that Mr Beazley is out there having the cheek to claim credit for what the government is now doing in this area. This is the gentleman who managed to distinguish himself recently by saying on commercial radio that he is no genius. We know what that means—that is code for, `I'm not terribly bright.' If you think the people of Australia are looking for someone who is running around as a chronic underachiever, not prepared to disguise his quite well justified modesty on the issue, then quite clearly you are in very big trouble. Mr Beazley said:

I've got to be honest about these things. Sometimes people arrive on the political scene, men of true genius. I'm not. I'm probably the most experienced Labor leader there has been, through no fault of my own.
In other words, he does not have merit or experience going for him. He then went on to say:
But I've tried to be constructive.

I would like to know what he means by that. They certainly have not been constructive in the area of small business. They certainly have not been constructive in the area of workplace reform. They certainly were not constructive in the area of allowing people to buy shares in Telstra. They have ditched enterprise bargaining. They have gone back to the future. They are now utterly beholden to the trade union movement.

The scandalous attack we saw mounted on ACOSS recently no doubt came straight from the Robert Ray charm school, with Senator Conroy thinking the only way back into the political game was to get out there and belt up on defenceless policy analysts. Once again, that will be exposed for what it is—crass political intimidation.

Their litany of failure to lead—in fact, leading from behind—is distinguished even more, not just by their backflips on work for the dole or Hindmarsh Island or, particularly, tariffs but also by their sneaky backflips over greenhouse gases and the immigration intake. In other words, it is perfectly clear from all that has been going on on the other side of politics and from all of these grandstanding performances by the young roosters that Senator Ray and his colleagues are perfectly happy to see Kim Beazley wallowing in the ratings. Senator Ray's latest preferred candidate, Simon Crean, would not want to have it any other way.

That is fine by us, but I think it ought to be well understood out there that you do not have any solutions to these problems. George Campbell actually got it right when he said a matter of months ago:
I do not think the party knows or has a clear perception of what it stands for.
That says it all. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Kemp representing the Acting Minister for Administrative Services. What action did Carolyn Hughes take after being alerted by Philomena Bisshop that Mr Jull had misled the parliament by tabling documents which highlighted repayments of travel allowance by former Labor ministers but covered up repayments by government ministers? Did she inform her superior officers? Did she or they inform the minister's office? If so, what was the reaction of the minister's office? Why was no action taken to correct the parliamentary record at the earliest possible opportunity?

—In Senator Faulkner's question there were a whole host of assumptions, none of which have been effectively demonstrated. Senator, you have asked me a question which relates to the Acting Minister for Administrative Services. I will refer your question to him to see whether he wishes to make a response.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I would have thought it was appropriate that, if the minister does not know the answers to the questions, he take them on notice and provide responses. I am sure the parliament and the public, Minister, expect nothing less. After you have supplied answers on notice to the questions I asked in my primary question, given that the Prime Minister has tabled the documentation related to his department's peripheral involvement in this affair, will you undertake to table all documentation relating to the involvement of the Department of Administrative Services in the matter?
—I will refer that question to the acting minister. I will be happy to provide the Senate with a response.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Yesterday the Sydney Futures Exchange opened an electricity futures market. In the light of the importance of developing a competitive national electricity market, what are the obstacles that stand in the way of New South Wales consumers benefiting from low electricity prices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Heffernan for that question, which is particularly timely. The New South Wales cabinet this morning endorsed the privatisation of the state's electricity industry. Of course, there is going to be the mother of all brawls over electricity reform at the state Labor conference on Friday.

ANSWER.PARA: The Sydney Futures Exchange yesterday opened an electricity futures market, which is an important advance on the development of a competitive national market for electricity. The futures market will help electricity suppliers and distributors keep the price of electricity as low as possible because they will be able to control the risks they face and will have more information about the demand and the supply of power.

As a result of the development of the national electricity market, spot prices have fallen almost 35 per cent from $23 per megawatt hour to $15 per megawatt hour. The New South Wales government is continuing the electricity reform process with its plans to privatise the state's electricity assets. The privatisation of the New South Wales power industry will not only raise $25 billion but will also result in lower electricity prices.

There is intense opposition from sections of the ALP to privatising the power industry in New South Wales. I want to know where the federal opposition stands on this issue. Where does Senator Faulkner stand on this issue? Where does Senator Forshaw stand on this issue? Where does Senator Neal stand on this issue? We know where Senator George Campbell stands on this issue. Not only was he content, according to the previous Prime Minister, with having the blood of 90,000 unemployed on his hands; he now wants to add more to the total.

It is curious, isn't it? Mr Brereton and Mr McLeay, who represent the New South Wales Right, are sneaking around behind the back of Mr Beazley, who said this is entirely a New South Wales issue, opposing the sale on the grounds that it would be harder for them to campaign against the partial sale of Telstra at the next federal election. What absolute hypocrisy! What double standards! It was these people that sold off Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank.

The opposition of these members of the New South Wales Right is, of course, in the historic tradition of the way they operate. They are completely prepared to sacrifice the economic interests of the people of New South Wales in the interests of short‐term political opportunism, to the disadvantage of their own state Labor government and, particularly, Michael Egan.

Presumably, Senator Faulkner, you are a delegate to this conference and it is about time you came clean on what you think about electricity reform. After all, you were a minister in the previous government that sold off Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank.

TALK.START.PARA: —No‐one has ever questioned my vote before.

—I urge you, Senator Faulkner, to stand up for the people of New South Wales and support Michael Egan and Premier Carr, rather than lining up with your traditional factional enemies. I know that Mr Beazley has admitted that he is not a good leader, but I do call on him to bring his troops into line and to support his colleagues in the New South Wales government.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Minister, can you explain why, yesterday, you categorically defended the Prime Minister's refusal to table the Sutherland statement on the basis that `it relates, obviously, to only one side of the events'? A curious statement in itself, I must say. You insisted that this was `the real reason' and that `there was nothing extraordinary in it at all'. Don't you agree, Minister, that what was extraordinary was that, half an hour after you made this categorical defence, the Prime Minister actually tabled the statement? Why were you unaware of this? Why were you not briefed on the tabling and the content of the documents? And what is the use of having you in here representing the Prime Minister when you are clearly so far out of the loop?

—Madam President, I think I would describe it as the precautionary approach. I explained why the Prime Minister had declined to table it the previous week. I explained the differences that occurred in the meantime as a result of the statement of the Auditor‐General. And, if I can remember correctly, I think I actually said that I thought the Prime Minister might be making a statement.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, can you confirm that three major private employment agencies in Australia—Adecco, Morgan and Banks, and Manpower Australia—have not tendered to participate in the government's new private sector employment system because, they said, they do not consider the terms to be commercially viable?

QUESTION.PARA: Do you regard this as a bit of a bad start, Minister, because haven't you been arguing that there would be sufficient incentive for the private sector to do the job more efficiently than the CES? Do you agree with Wallace Brown, whose comments appeared in the Sunday Mail just over a week ago, that this is a case of `practicality being sacrificed for ideology' and that, for once, the CES could do this job better?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Kernot for the opportunity to give the Senate an update on the outcomes of the tender processes as we thus know them and at the same time answer, in the first instance, your last question: do I believe the CES can necessarily do this job better than anyone else. No.
—You said the previous practicalities, Senator.

—Senator, you have asked your question and I am just giving you an answer on the basis of what you asked. I am trying to clarify for you my view. It is not that the CES could do this job better. The previous government did not believe that. It was the previous government that introduced competition in employment services, that brought in the private sector and that brought in community groups. We agree with that innovation of the previous government. It was one of the few good things in the Working Nation program and we intend to continue that competition between government, private and community sector organisations.

BREAK.PARA: The important point is that unemployed Australians who are on benefits, who are eligible for this type of assistance, will be able to choose who they think will best help them. This is not Big Brother saying, `You must go to the CES.' This is a government saying, `You can choose the provider of your choice. If you want to go to a community provider, you do so. If they get you a job, we'll pay the bill. If you want to go to a private provider that has tendered and been successful, then you go there. And, if they get you a job, we'll pay the bill. If you would like to go to the government provider, not the privatised provider'—there is not a privatised CES; it has been corporatised; we still own the whole lot of it—`you go there and we'll pay the bill.'

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the three agencies?

—If you don't mind, Senator, you have asked the question and I am making the odd assumption that you are interested in the answer. Unemployed Australians will walk into the premises of their choice knowing not that they are someone who is expecting to get something for nothing—a service provided by the government at the CES—but that they are a valued client and that, if the service is provided—that is, if the person gets a job—the business will get the money.
—You are not answering me.

—I am coming to the rest of your question, but I wanted to answer that aspect fully. Senator, there must be a very long list of organisations that did not tender. Good luck to them; that is their choice. But let me explain something to you: the tender has not been prepared in order to allow private sector people to make huge amounts of money out the unemployed. If people are not tendering because they do not think it is commercial enough and that there is not enough profit in it for them, then that is their decision and I am not worried about that, because the tender was prepared with two things in mind: delivering better services to unemployed people and having contracts—unlike most of the contracts drawn up under new work opportunities, the remnants of which we see in the existing programs where CES managers negotiated very substantial contracts that did not, in the end, deliver. This contract is a tight contract in the Commonwealth's favour; that is, taxpayers' money is protected.

BREAK.PARA: There are two quite clear purposes behind this tender: better services for unemployed Australians and protection of taxpayers' money. If someone says, `Well, I don't want that; there's not enough room in there for me to make a buck', I do not care because my job is not to help people make money. My job is to design a system that helps more people get jobs.

As to the tender, over 1,000 organisations from across Australia have submitted tenders. They have been received from each of the 29 labour market regions, with an excellent response of some 5,000 bids across all service types, that is, flex, entry level training support services and the new enterprise incentive scheme. I think that number of bids across the 29 regions demonstrates the value of the very extensive consultations that were undertaken with the market from September 1996. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer. You spent a long time on the theory of how it should work but I would like you to tell us more about the design of your system. If you cannot attract the big players like this, does that put a much higher burden on the community and charitable organisations? The emphasis in your answer was on organisations. What kind of people are really tendering for this, Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —When I have more information in relation to this matter and can give you details of who has tendered and who has not, I will be happy to do that. But I am not going to interfere in the tender process in any way. No member of the government would and I certainly would not think any member of the opposition would.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a simple point that you need to understand, Senator. I have tried to explain this to you time and again. You are not usually regarded as completely stupid, but you just do not have a grip on this. The purpose of this is to give unemployed Australians a choice. If they do not choose to go to the community providers and they choose to go to the government provider, I will be happy because my job is to give unemployed Australians a better service and give them a choice. That is the Liberal way—give people a choice. If they choose the government provider, I am very happy with that. I do not care who they choose. You say that we should put more pressure on community providers. Community providers would be happy to have larger contracts. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Administrative Services. Can you confirm media reports that the general manager of the Ministerial and Parliamentary Services Division, Mr Graham Semmens, has been stood down? Is he being made a scapegoat for the political machinations concocted within the office of the former Minister for Administrative Services? Has Mr Semmens received a formal request to explain his knowledge of contacts between the Department of Administrative Services and the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and DAS and the Prime Minister's office?
—In relation to that question by Senator Lundy, I do have a brief here.
—You haven't read it yet.

The advice that I have from the Acting Minister for Administrative Services is that, contrary to media reports, no officer of the Department of Administrative Services has been stood down at this stage.

—My question is directed to Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environment, the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Trade. With respect to timber imports and the context highlighted by the Indonesian forest fires, which are widely considered to be a result of unsustainable forestry and land clearing practice, coupled with an unusually strong El Nino southern oscillation event, is there any way Australia can discriminate between timber and timber products produced by sustainable forestry practices and those produced by unsustainable practices? Is it possible to restrict imports or place higher tariffs on products of unsustainable logging? I note that several nations have made efforts to manage their forests on a sustainable basis while others have not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does recognise the importance of ensuring that the world's forests are managed sustainably, both because of the environmental and economic consequences of doing otherwise. It is for that reason that Australia is involved in a range of international fora and activities designed to encourage the adoption of ecologically sustainable forest management in nations that have within their boundaries commercially utilised forest resources.

ANSWER.PARA: Principal among those fora is the newly created International Forum on Forests, which is the high level group recently established by the international community and which will actually be holding its first meeting next week in New York. The IFF brings together most forested nations, including Indonesia and Malaysia, and has responsibility for overseeing the implementation of the recommendations of its predecessor, the International Panel on Forests.

Chief among those recommendations is the adoption of sustainable forest management through mechanisms such as the development of national forest programs, the sharing of knowledge between countries about forest management and the development of international criteria and indicators that will allow nations to establish measurable benchmarks. In relation to that point, I would also add that Australia has been one of the leading nations in encouraging the work of what is known as the Montreal process, which is seeking to establish criteria and indicators for sustainable forest management in countries containing temperate forests, such as our own.

BREAK.PARA: Australia is also pursuing the issue of sustainable forest management within tropical timber producing countries through the International Tropical Timber Organisation, which is seeking to ensure that the tropical forests in member nations are managed sustainably by the year 2000. More specifically, my department and that of Minister Anderson are jointly funding the development of an Asia‐Pacific code of practice for forest harvesting for our region. We are working with Indonesia, the lead nation for the code, and other regional neighbours to ensure its completion. At this stage we anticipate that it will be considered for adoption by the regional body of the FAO next February.

The government has also been involved in the international dialogue on the issue of certification and labelling. As Senator Margetts would know, a range of groups, such as the Worldwide Fund for Nature, have been advocating an international certification system that would allow consumers to discriminate between sustainably and unsustainably produced timber. We believe the debate about issues such as these is important. That is why we hosted a major international conference on certification and labelling in Brisbane last year.

The government is concerned about unsustainable forest practices, and we are taking measures to work cooperatively with our neighbours in other countries to ensure that those concerns are addressed. We believe that it is through cooperative action and the sharing of information that we can actually produce meaningful changes in the ways that other nations manage their forests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has indicated the ability of consumers to discriminate by means of labelling. Does that mean the minister will be putting to his government that Australia will participate in labelling that clearly discriminates between sustainable and unsustainable forest practices? Do I take it from the minister's answer that there will be no efforts at all by Australia in the meantime to provide disincentives for Australians who provide a market for unsustainable forestry practices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said, our approach has been to encourage practices that will ensure the sustainable management of forests offshore. We are doing that through the international mechanisms that I referred to in some detail. We also accept that there is a right of consumers to choose, and that is why we have been supporting the development of certification and labelling which is being adopted by some non‐government organisations. In those circumstances, consumers have a choice, and we will continue to support the development of such processes.

ANSWER.PARA: We will also continue to fund the sorts of programs that I have been talking about. In the last two years AusAID, a government agency, has in fact increased its contribution to these activities, now averaging some $10 million per annum. This is in addition to the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research, which now spends more than $4 million per annum on forestry research. So we are taking these issues very seriously.(Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Minister, I refer to Ms McKenna's resignation letter of 25 September, which was tabled in the House by the Prime Minister yesterday. Ms McKenna's letter states:

QUESTION.PARA: I must reiterate, however, that my conversation with John Sutherland in May concerning repayment of travel allowances by certain National Party Members and Senators was of the most general kind . . .

Minister, given that at no time in recent days in the parliament or in the House has there been any correspondence released on this matter referring to National Party senators, will you guarantee that there have been no secret repayments made by National Party senators? How do you explain Ms McKenna's reference? While you are on your feet, would you like to guarantee—we have not had an answer yet—that no other minister has made a secret repayment of travel allowances since you were sworn into office on 11 March? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know of any repayment by anyone else. I have been around long enough not to wish to guarantee anything that I do not know of my own knowledge. The statements made by Ms McKenna have just been stated by you, and I do not see there is anything constructive that I can add to those. She said, to use my words, that her memory was of a discussion in very broad terms—and obviously in such general terms, non‐specific terms, that she did not see a need to take it further.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I understand your answer, Senator Hill, but I am really asking you why in that letter of resignation, which was a considered document, Ms McKenna nominated not only National Party members but also National Party senators, none of whom have been mentioned by the Prime Minister or anywhere else in any correspondence. I am seeking an explanation as to whether you have satisfied yourself that all your coalition colleagues in the National Party have their travel allowance in order and whether any of them have in fact made a repayment that is yet to be notified in public.

—It is difficult to ask me to interpret the statement of another, and that is what you are doing in relation to Ms McKenna. I have said to you that I have no knowledge of any other repayments. I suspect that what she is doing is talking of National Party members of parliament. Another way of expressing it is to talk of `members and senators', but that is only something that I would surmise. I have no reason to believe that there has been any repayment by a senator.

—My question is directed to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training recently produced a report entitled Youth employment: a working solution . Will you inform the Senate of the status of this report and give an indication of the government's likely response?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Macdonald for the question. I understand that the report was tabled in parliament yesterday. It followed a national inquiry into the employment of young people that I was very keen to see proceed. The government very much appreciates the work of committees such as this one because they make a very valuable contribution to the debate on such vitally important areas.

ANSWER.PARA: The government will take some time to digest the recommendations made and to provide an appropriate response, but it will be done as soon as possible. We very much welcome the strong case that is made by the majority members of the committee for the retention of age based junior rates. Obviously the majority members of the committee are aware of how irresponsible it would be to abolish age based junior rates.

These rates are absolutely essential for letting young Australians gain a foothold in the labour market. They give them a cost advantage. Far from disadvantaging junior employees, they actually assist them to get jobs. The current junior award arrangements that have been in place for the last 70 years or so should be retained within the scope of the awards system for the parties to establish skills based wage arrangements where this will not damage youth employment. At the same time, it is important that I indicate very clearly that this government will not be replacing existing junior traineeship and apprenticeship wages with a national youth wage.

The government is also committed to ensuring that young people are the winners with the government's new youth allowance. It is true: when you restructure, there are winners and losers. However, it is now less attractive to leave school early and not do any training. But young Australians will, in the end, be the winners.

The incentives have finally been rejigged away from remaining unskilled and toward the benefits of a good education and training. The youth allowance will provide students with much better financial support. It will remove financial incentives that have in the past seen young people choose to receive unemployment benefits rather than undertake further education and training. In addition to those matters, the government is delivering on its promise to increase genuine job opportunities for young Australians.

The new national apprenticeship system will provide trainees with world class skills, giving Australian businesses a competitive edge in the global economy. The federal government will provide a total of more than $1.3 billion for vocational education and training in 1997-98, which is an increase of $144 million or 12 per cent on funding provided in the last year of the Labor government. It includes $265 million for more than 100,000 new apprenticeships and traineeships in this financial year. The new apprenticeships and traineeships will be in high growth industries, such as technology, finance, tourism, hospitality and sport as well as the traditional trades.

In 1997-98, $415 million is being provided for the new national apprenticeship system. For the first time, there will be national recognition of skills and qualifications, thereby expanding job and career options. Employers will be able to choose who will deliver the off‐the‐job training of their apprentices and trainees. Hiring apprentices and trainees will be easier through one-stop shop arrangements. Students will now be able to earn while they learn by combining a paid new apprenticeship with their secondary education, and we will also be committing almost four times as much funding for VET in schools as the Labor Party provided over its last 13 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Ellison, the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Minister, why has the government acted only now to try to stop the Australian Law Reform Commission's evidence on the Wik legislation going before the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Native Title, when for the last 21 years the Australian Law Reform Commission has been commenting on legislation and accepting invitations to appear before parliamentary committees, when it has both current and past references that relate to the subject matter covered by the Wik legislation, and when it has already prepared a submission for the government's own internal task force on Wik at the invitation of the government? Minister, is there any other explanation for the Attorney‐General's cover-up than that this government is embarrassed by the commission's exposure of innumerable and fundamental problems involved with Mr Howard's personal Wik legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, let me say to Senator Bolkus that there has been no cover-up. There has been no attempt by the Attorney-General to suppress the ALRC from giving evidence. I will table a letter from the Attorney-General to Alan Rose, who is the President of the Australian Law Reform Commission. There is no threat in that letter. In fact, I would refer Senator Bolkus to the transcript of an interview with Alan Rose on 2CN. He denied that he had been threatened. Any question of there having been any suppression or attempted suppression by the Attorney‐General is utterly false.

ANSWER.PARA: When one looks at the advice that the opposition commissioned from Harry Evans, you see that it starts off on the premise that the Attorney-General has suppressed evidence. What the opposition failed to tell the Clerk of the Senate was that the Attorney-General had not suppressed evidence and had not even tried to do so. So they misled the clerk.

What the Attorney-General was doing was pointing out to the ALRC its functions under the act. Under the act, it acts within references referred to it by the Attorney-General. In fact, in 1994 Daryl Melham, the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, recommended that that provision remain, that is, that the ALRC deal only with references referred to it by the Attorney-General.

Labor said that itself when it was in office previously. What we have here is an absolute beat-up of what the Attorney-General has done. They have tried to twist the communication by the Attorney‐General to the ALRC. This letter very plainly sets out the concerns of the Attorney-General. There is no question of suppression. The information from the transcript where Alan Rose was interviewed reveals that he was not threatened. The attack by the opposition in relation to this is thoroughly spurious and on unsubstantiated grounds. I table the letter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, were the submissions of the Australian Law Reform Commission to the National Commission of Audit in May last year, to the Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee's inquiry into contracting out earlier this year and to the recent joint CPA inquiry into the Public Service Bill in accordance with the commission's strict terms of reference? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very important question, not just for this parliament but also for all those parents who have gone through the anguish of divorce and the charged emotions in those circumstances. The government has been working very hard to address the remaining recommendations which the joint select committee made prior to our coming into government. You would recognise that there is a very great concern in the community at what are perceived to be inequities both in the way the system is administered and in the formula.

ANSWER.PARA: The details will be announced this afternoon. The reforms underscore the principle that children are the financial responsibility of both their parents and that the government should not seek to intrude unnecessarily into people's lives, but that government involvement will provide the safety net to ensure children of separated parents are adequately supported and that the general community is not asked to carry an undue burden.

The agreed package which we are announcing today includes: changes to the calculation of child support liabilities payments, recognising that after separation some payers do not have sufficient means to support themselves and their second families; additional assistance to many thousands of children by introducing a minimum payment of child support and by including a wider range of income when assessing child support liability; parents will be able to move from the Child Support Agency collection to private collection by agreement at any time, allowing the Child Support Agency to concentrate on those people who are unable to reach a private agreement; parents will be required to move into private collection where they have a consistent payment record, but the Child Support Agency will continue to provide a safety net if the new arrangements fail; support programs, including self‐help, education, mediation and help for payers, to encourage parents to make private collection arrangements; and a range of important administrative reforms which will make the scheme more responsive to people's needs by, for example, so streamlining arrangements that the payments are made up to 20 days earlier, and including the right to object to any Child Support Agency decision.

Of the 163 recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues, 111 have now been addressed. The remaining 52 recommendations will be addressed shortly. Eleven recommendations were addressed in the legislation that this government passed in June 1997 and 53 were addressed by the previous government's interim response. Today's reforms, which in many cases will lead to significantly simplified and more reliable payment arrangements, are a very positive step in what is a difficult and highly emotional social area, as I have said.

For the first time, where parents can make sensible arrangements for their children's support, as is the case with the majority of Child Support Agency clients, the new private payment arrangements give them a chance to get on with their lives without unnecessary bureaucratic intervention. Many senators would realise that that has been a major contributor to the frustrations of parents. It may also herald a better deal for children, who deserve to have the continuing involvement of both parents in their lives. These are good, sound changes and they will be welcomed by all interested parties. The changes will provide real benefits to Child Support Agency clients by introducing much needed flexibility into the administration of the child support system and by improving its timeliness, accuracy and responsiveness.

—The clerk of what?

—The Clerk of the Senate, I should say. What we have here is a situation where the opposition embellished on the facts. They put to the clerk a situation which they regarded as a fait accompli. So, when they say they have advice, the opposition have to clarify precisely the terms of the brief upon which that advice was obtained. When you look at that letter, you can see that it is quite plain that there was no such attempt to interfere with Mr Alan Rose and the evidence he was thinking of giving.

SPEECH.PARA: The other side of the coin is that Mr Rose has been interviewed by the press and he said that there was no threat. So you have corroboration from Mr Rose, President of the ALRC, who says he was not threatened. So where is the threat here? Again, that dispenses with the allegation by the opposition that there has been any attempt by the Attorney‐General to interfere with evidence which was going to be given by the ALRC or was contemplated being given.

On the other hand, there is a statutory aspect to this. The Australian Law Reform Commission is a body which is set up by statute, the Australian Law Reform Commission Act 1996, which deals with the powers of that body. That body can only do those things which are within the act, and that is the point the Attorney‐General was making. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to speak on the answer given to Senator Bolkus's question. I think that Senator Ellison's contribution today has in fact helped to establish the case. He relied on the letter the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) presented in his defence, but I think that answers the central question involved in that issue, and that is why and when did the Attorney‐General decide to act on the question of the Australian Law Reform Commission's involvement in these issues. The answer to that is that he decided to act when he read their advice to the Wik task force, when he decided that their advice was politically incorrect and did not fit with the government's own political objectives and that their criticisms would expose and blow away the government's whole rationale for its supposed 10‐point plan, which now consists of more than 290 pages of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney‐General chose to act because he did not like what he read. It has got nothing to do with the process arguments that Senator Ellison so conveniently wraps himself in because that is his only line of defence: to argue about process and to divert from the real issue. The real issue is that the government did not like the advice. They did not like the politics of the advice, and they did the same thing they do with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and any other form of independent advice they get that they do not like—they attack that source of advice, they try and close down that advice, try and restrict the advice, because they do not want competing points of view. They do not want people saying, `Hang on. We have a different view of the world. We have a different bit of legal advice as to how you should be responding to problems in society.'

The third thing they do after that is to attack the individuals involved. What we have seen since is an attempt by Mr Williams and by Mr Entsch, the chair of the native title committee, to play the man, to attack those involved. They want to denigrate them because they do not like the advice. The key issue is why and when Mr Williams responded, and he responded, as was made clear by Mr Rose today in an interview with Ross Solly, because he did not like the advice. I quote Mr Rose because people have been saying, `Oh, he was not really threatened.' He said:

Last Tuesday I had a conversation with the Acting Secretary to the Attorney‐General's Department, Norman Reaburn, in which he conveyed to me the very great dislike which the Attorney had for the proposal that we were proposing to put to the parliamentary committee, that is, he, the Attorney‐General, was strongly opposed to that draft submission, which we had provided him a copy of, being made to the commission.

In other words, it was not the fact that they were commenting that concerned the Attorney‐General. It was the fact of what they were saying because they have blown the Wik legislation right out of the water. They expose it as being unfair, unjust, unconstitutional and as not providing the certainty that the government should provide. It is the content of the advice which the government do not want to accept. So they seek to close down the Law Reform Commission in terms of it providing that sort of advice in the future, they are trying to stifle them from appearing before the native title committee and now they are starting to attack individuals.
The chair of the native title committee, Mr Warren Entsch, a member of the House of Representatives, added to that today. When asked about the Law Reform Commission, he said:
From what I have seen they are offering absolutely nothing more than what has been pushed by the Labor Party and some groups within the Aboriginal community.
He went on to say:

BREAK.PARA: It raises a question, given the appointment within the Australian Law Reform Commission. It came out today that Alan Rose is a Keating appointee.

TALK.START.PARA: —How shocking!

—Well, shock horror! This bloke was appointed by the Keating government and it is totally unacceptable that someone like that appear before a parliamentary committee. Where will it stop? This was the response. This is the attitude the government have to any advice that they do not agree with.

BREAK.PARA: They used to accuse the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, of promoting political correctness. What we are seeing here is a far worse example than anything you saw under a Labor government regarding political correctness: `If you do not agree with us and if you do not provide advice that we like we will stop you from saying it and we will stop you from appearing before a committee of the parliament. We will try and cover up the advice that you provide because we cannot deal with the intellectual arguments contained in it; we cannot refute them.'

TALK.START.PARA: —We will denigrate you personally.

—Then, if that does not work, `We will get out there in the media and start denigrating you personally.' It is the same sort of thing that happened to Ronald Wilson when he was President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. You did not like what he had to say so you had to denigrate him. That is exactly what has gone on with Alan Rose in the last couple of days. It is a disgrace. There will be a lot more said on this issue because what has occurred is a cover‐up and a breach of privilege. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —The thrust of this attack seems to be that the Australian Law Reform Commission should be making comments on matters that are not the subject of a reference, which I must say is a novel way to look at it; that the Australian Law Reform Commission can exceed its power, it can run around and make a submission to any committee it likes and it can do so with impunity; that it can talk on any topic it likes, anything that takes its fancy, and can use up the resources that it is supposed to be using for the references it does have in deciding what it might rather do; and that it can go around without a reference and just exceed its power. Had the Attorney‐General, Mr Williams, been aware a little earlier that the commission was making a practice of making submissions to committees on matters for which it did not have a reference, I am quite certain that he would have had something more to say about that. Clearly, he took the matter up when he said that he also expressed concerns in relation to the commission making submissions on matters such as copyright, for which there is no current reference.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue here is not the content of this submission. It is not the content that is in issue, nor is it the fact that the commission has gone and, off its own bat, decided that it should make references on other topics. The issue is what power it has to do it. The issue is whether it should be making submissions to inquiries and committees on subject matters that just take its fancy from time to time.

If one comes back to the Clerk of the Senate's letter one sees a very interesting distinction, and that is in a subsequent letter dated 29 September from the clerk to Senator Faulkner. The letter said:

It has been revealed by answer to a question in the Senate that the Attorney‐General suggested or directed that the Commission not make a submission to the joint committee because the Commission does not have a current relevant reference and that the government wishes that the Commission confine itself to the subjects of its references.

A lot has been said here today and I do not need to repeat the fact that it is patently obvious that if you give someone a false assumption on which to write an advice you get the wrong advice. The letter goes on to say:

It appears from public comments by the President of the Commission that it was indicated that the government might give a direction to restrict the activities of the Commission if the Attorney‐General's suggestion or direction was not heeded.

How could anyone take that as a threat? What you are saying here is that if the commission does not observe its terms of reference and if it does not do what it is constituted and set up to do then, by gee, you will restrict its activities; you will do something about it. That is the Attorney‐General's duty.

It is absolute nonsense not to have made that distinction. It is patently dishonest not to have made that distinction and to have asked the clerk to comment when the assumption is entirely fallacious and is also totally mischievous. This is a total and utter beat‐up of something that everyone knows is where the commission is simply exceeding its powers. The Attorney‐General has, of course, categorically denied that there is any threat and his statement has actually been agreed with by Mr Rose, the president of the commission. Apparently Mr Rose does not think that he has been threatened, Mr Williams says that he was not threatened, so who on earth thinks he was threatened?

It is ultimately a matter for the commission to decide whether or not to comment on the native title bill. I suppose it is a matter for the commission to decide whether it is going to carry out its proper function and attend to the references and matters that it has in front of it or whether it is going to go completely outside its powers and try and comment upon something else.

The Attorney‐General has asserted, and it is absolutely correct, that he has at all times acted in accordance with his duties as the minister with the portfolio responsibilities for the commission. He said—and indeed he would have been remiss and would have failed in his duty if he had not made it known—to the commission that it should only act within the powers conferred on it by the parliament. Everyone is going on here about the powers of the parliament. One has to always act within power and I am absolutely astounded that anyone with an ounce of legal nous could think that somebody should act without power and make submissions about it to this place or to some properly constituted Senate committee. It beggars believe that that could be contended. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Democracy has actually taken a fair old hiding over the last 18 months when you have a look at the parade now of organisations and individuals that the government has attempted to emasculate and publicly denigrated if they dared express an opinion in this democracy of ours not welcome to the government.

SPEECH.PARA: I do want to spend just a minute or two talking about that, because I thought it was a very low moment indeed in Australian democracy when the federal Attorney-General (Mr Williams) denigrated the professional integrity of Mr Rose as a lawyer—and a very competent and senior lawyer in the Australian constitutional establishment—on the basis that Mr Rose had been appointed to the position he held by Mr Keating when he was Prime Minister.

That was an appalling attack not worthy of Mr Williams and it is a side of Mr Williams I have not seen before. Maybe he wants to look hairy chested at the moment because of all the press that he is not hairy chested enough and is likely to be removed from his position. But it does him absolutely no credit at all.

But that was followed up this morning by a personal attack on Mr Rose by Warren Entsch, the chair of the Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal Torres Strait Islander Land Fund. Was the chair of the committee acting on the committee's behalf when he publicly attacked Mr Rose on the basis—to quote Warren Entsch, and what an idiot statement it was—`it's come out today' that he was appointed to chair the Law Reform Commission by Prime Minister Keating. It was actually announced at the time by Michael Lavarch. Cabinet appointed Mr Rose, and rightly so, on the recommendation of Mr Lavarch as Attorney-General. I think it can be fairly said that Mr Lavarch had the respect of both sides of parliament and certainly the legal profession as the then Attorney-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think so, Bob.
—You are a shyster, Senator Macdonald, and I have no trouble denigrating you. But just reflect for a minute on the stupidity—
—I didn't fail my exams like you did.
—You are going to get a promotion, are you? I hope so.
—Order Senator Collins! Would you like to withdraw some language which I considered somewhat unparliamentary, please?

—I will withdraw anything you like, Madam Deputy President. Let us have a look at the stupidity of this attack. Can I remind Mr Williams, and indeed Warren Entsch, the chair of the committee, that I think it was utterly inappropriate for the chair of this committee to attack a potential witness apparently, according to the government now, before he had appeared before the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, Mr Rose—for the information of those people—actually worked in the office of the then Prime Minister of Australia, Malcolm Fraser. Mr Rose occupied senior positions in the bureaucracy throughout the entire period of the Fraser government. Mr Rose then became the Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department federally. So it was hardly an unreasonable appointment to appoint Mr Rose. The Attorney-General of Australia has publicly denigrated this person and that was followed up by the chair of the joint committee attacking him—a highly qualified and respected member of the Australian legal community—this morning on AM on the basis that he finally did achieve that position as president.

Why were they doing so? It was because they did not like the advice. As several senators have already pointed out, the practice of the commission has been to comment on these matters of high public policy. The commission was in fact specifically and in writing invited to do so by Senator Nick Minchin, who forwarded them a copy of the bill and asked them to comment on it. When they did comment on it, the government attacked the advice. Why will you not allow this advice in this democracy of ours to be tabled? Why will you not allow the Law Reform Commission to appear and give this advice to the committee and debate the advice on its merits?

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't like it.
—I am not surprised that they do not like it. Just listen to this example from it:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission believes that not only are the declared objectives of the bill mutually inconsistent, in particular competing notions of the preservation of native title and the validation of confirmation by way of purported extinguishment of native title of prior grants or property rights, but also that the proposed means by which they are to be achieved are inadequate and counterproductive.

The advice goes on in equally critical vein to in fact assert that the two potential heads of constitutional power under which this bill is going to go through this parliament in fact are not constitutionally valid.

This is advice that should be presented to this joint committee. This is a matter of high public policy according to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) himself. Why is this advice being gagged? It is because the government does not like it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us debunk something that Senator Bob Collins, the former shadow minister and now backbencher, suggested to this Senate—that the practice of the Australian Law Reform Commission was to make comment on these important matters. Let us go through what the Australian Law Reform Commission did not comment on in relation to these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: As I am advised, the Native Title Amendment Bill 1995 of the previous government was not commented on by the Australian Law Reform Commission. Then the government's May 1996 discussion paper on the amendments was not commented on. The subsequent 1996 amendment bill was not commented upon by the Australian Law Reform Commission, and, might I add, quite properly. They should not have and they did not. What was so peculiar about this particular occasion that made the Australian Law Reform Commission consider it necessary for them to comment? I think we know the answer to that.

The important point is that the suggestion has been made that we on this side of politics and the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) have somehow tried to stop the Australian Law Reform Commission from pursuing its submission to the parliamentary joint committee. I am advised that the fact is that the secretariat of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund has not received a submission from the Australian Law Reform Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —They received a letter.
—There is no paper document in front of them.
—They have written it.

—No. The submission was to the Wik task force and it was on that occasion that the Attorney-General wrote to the Australian Law Reform Commission saying `this is out of your terms of reference' when he became aware of it. Might I add as an aside that he has also told the Australian Law Reform Commission about the less controversial issue of copyright law, `It is out of bounds; you should not be commenting on it.'

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most galling things for me as the chair of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee was to have the Australian Law Reform Commission come to us before estimates and complain about lack of resources to do their job adequately on those matters which they are in fact required to report on when they then go on frolics of their own spending taxpayers' money on issues that they have not been requested to look into.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep going. You have 57 minutes—57 seconds.

—You nearly made my day when you said I had another 57 minutes, Madam Deputy President. But, quite frankly, it does not take 57 minutes or 57 seconds to debunk the nonsense that the opposition has tried to put before us today. We on this side know that when the opposition are on really weak ground and do not really have their heart in it, who else do they get to lead the charge for them but Senator Bolkus, who has no credibility on this side of the chamber or on that side of the chamber or indeed in the community at large.
—Mr Political Advertising!

—We now know that Senator Bolkus, the man who did not want political advertising in this country on TV, is all of a sudden a convert to free speech to allow people to act outside their terms of reference. It is a joke. We can see through it. It is transparency at its worst. The allegations are dismissed. (Time expired)

PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia, call on all Senators to support implementation of the following:

PARA.TAB: a requirement to label with the production process, all foods from genetic engineering technologies or containing their products;
real public participation in decisions on whether to allow commercialisation of foods, additives and processing agents produced by gene technologies;
premarket human trials and strict safety rules on these foods, to assess production processes as well as the end products.

PETITION.PARA: Precedents which support our petition include several examples of foods already labelled with the processes of production; irradiated foods (here and internationally); certified organic foods; and many conventional foods (pasteurised; salt‐reduced; free‐range; vitamin‐enriched; to name only a few).
We ask you all to accord a high priority to supporting and implementing our petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned recognises the vital role of a strong and comprehensive Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and asks that:
1. Coalition Senators honour their 1996 election promise, namely that "The Coalition will maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC".
2. The Senate votes to maintain the existing role of the ABC as a fully independent, publicly funded and publicly owned organisation.
3. The Senate oppose any weakening of the Charter of the ABC.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

This petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are still the only Australians, sent overseas on active service, whose service has not been recognised in three important areas:
1. R.A.N. casualties are not yet included on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial alongside Army and R.A.A.F. casualties;
2. R.A.N. service has not yet been recognised with the visible signs of service to Australia; the Returned from Active Service Badge and the Naval campaign medal; and
3. R.A.N. service is still not acknowledged as eligible service for the Australian Service Pension, while service by Commonwealth and allied veterans from 55 other countries is.
Members of the Army and R.A.A.F. who served during the same period in Malaya had their service fully recognised 24 hours after arriving in Malaya.

In the 1997 Budget the Government partly recognised that R.A.N. service was `operational' and accepted responsibility for disabilities resulting from that service. Those affected appreciate the belated, partial recognition. However, government departments are still resorting to old, and inventing new excuses, to deny the above 3 points.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate acts to help remove the injustice of 40 years and fully recognise R.A.N. service by providing the same recognition and benefits for that service. The cost will be minuscule, being mainly a transfer of pensions from `age' as paid by the Department of Social Security, to `service' pensions, paid by the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Allison, Sen Lyn; Woodley, Sen John; Brown, Sen Bob
PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide employment in composting, soil remineralisation programs, and the planting of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

The statements read as follows—

These Bills amend the Customs Tariff Act 1995 (the Customs Tariff) and the Excise Tariff Act 1921 (the Excise Tariff) to ensure the continuation of the Commonwealth's safety net to protect State and Territory revenues following the decision of the High Court in the cases of Ngo Ngo Ha v State of New South Wales and Walter Hammond and Associates P/L v State of New South Wales

Customs and excise duties on petroleum products currently dutiable at $0.36872 per litre and $0.34697 per litre will be increased by 8.1 cents per litre. These increases will be implemented by the Customs Tariff Amendment Act (No. 3) 1997 and the Excise Tariff Amendment Act (No. 3) 1997.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1997 and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1997 are necessary due to the effect that the package of Bills which contain measures to address fuel substitution and blending practices (the Fuel Substitution Package) will have on the parts of the Customs Tariff Act and the Excise Tariff Act that apply to petroleum products. These measures, which were introduced into the Parliament before the High Court decision, introduce differential rates of duty on petroleum products according to their end use and the presence of a chemical marker and have required a complete restructure of those parts of the Customs Tariff Act and the Excise Tariff Act that apply to petroleum products. Schedule 3 to the Customs Tariff Act will be amended by omitting and substituting most of the subheadings of Chapter 27 and The Schedule to the Excise Tariff Act will be amended by omitting and substituting item 11.

The purpose of the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) and Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) will be to incorporate these duty increases into the new structure of the Customs Tariff Act and the Excise Tariff Act in respect of petroleum products.

Introduction and passage during the 1997 Spring sittings is necessary so that the amendments can commence at the same time as the Fuel Substitution Package, which was introduced in the 1997 Winter sittings and is due for passage in the Spring sittings.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs, Senator the Hon Christopher Ellison)

The National Firearms Program Implementation Act 1996 provides authority for the Commonwealth to reimburse compensation paid by the States and Territory to firearm owners who are required to hand in firearms as a result of the 1996 National Agreement on Firearms Regulation.

The Amendment Bill will amend the Act to remedy an unintended limitation on what constitutes "qualifying compensation" for the purposes of reimbursement of compensation. The definition in section 3 refers to self-loading rifles, self-loading shotguns or pump-action shotguns which were the firearms which all Governments agreed to restrict as a result of the national agreements. The definition, as far as it goes, is correct.

The intention of the national agreements, however, was clearly to encourage the surrender of all prohibited firearms, whether they were historically prohibited or about to be prohibited. Those historically prohibited include such firearms as machine guns and sub-machine guns.
The buyback finishes nationally on 30 September 1997 and the bill is therefore urgent to ensure that qualifying compensation paid by the States and Territories is properly reimbursed.

FAMILY COURT OF WESTERN AUSTRALIA (ORDERS OF REGISTRARS) BILL 1997

The bill contains no new policy but overcomes technical deficiencies in the way Commonwealth and State family law legislation and Rules of Court have applied in Western Australia. Western Australia is the only State to have its own family court. The bill is designed to complement Western Australian legislation addressing these deficiencies from within the legislative capabilities of that State.

The bill will create family law rights and liabilities for the many people who may be affected by a recent decision of the Full Court of the Family Court of Australia in the matter of Horne v Horne 13 February 1997, Appeal No. WA 13 of 1996. In that case, the Full Family Court held that the Family Law Rule that purportedly allowed Registrars of the Family Court of Western Australia to exercise the power to make consent orders was invalid. As a result, many consent orders made by Registrars in Western Australia are ineffective.

This bill will overcome this problem by ensuring that all affected people in Western Australia obtain enforceable, statutory family law rights and liabilities that mirror the rights and liabilities that would have been created by valid Registrars' orders.

The approach taken in the bill is based on a similar one approved by the High Court in R v Humby ex parte Rooney (1973) 129 CLR 231 and subsequently in cases such as Polyukhovich v the Commonwealth (1991) 172 CLR 501. This approach does not attempt to validate the purported orders made by Registrars. Instead, it creates new statutory rights and liabilities that may be exercised and enforced in the same manner as orders.
The bill will not have any significant financial impact.
I commend the bill.
HEALTH INSURANCE COMMISSION (REFORM AND SEPARATION OF FUNCTIONS) BILL 1997
This bill provides for the separation of Medibank Private from the Health Insurance Commission (HIC), and the creation of a new Medibank Private corporation.

Through the separation, the Government will ensure that Medibank Private cannot be perceived to have any competitive advantage over other private health funds through its association with Medicare or other government programme functions of the HIC. It reinforces Government's commitment to the principle of competitive neutrality.
The new Medibank Private corporation, after a transitional period in which it will operate as a wholly-owned subsidiary of the HIC, will remain in public ownership.

The bill therefore provides for the HIC initially to hold shares in the nominated company and to seek registration of that company as a registered health benefits organisation under the National Health Act 1953. The HIC may not transfer any of its shares or voting rights attached to the shares before the date on which the shares are transferred to the Commonwealth.
Any change to these ownership arrangements can only be made by parliamentary amendment of this legislation.

The new company, once it is operating Medibank Private, will not be limited by the current provisions of the Health Insurance Commission Act to determine the range of activities that may be carried out by the company. This will ensure that Medibank Private, to all intents and purposes, will be able to compete on an even footing with other private health insurers.

The bill provides for the transfer of the fund and its business to the "nominated company" (not yet formed) which will operate Medibank Private. The HIC is specifically empowered by the bill to facilitate that transfer. The transfer scheme will be published in the Gazette.

Provision for the transfer of assets, contracts—including the splitting of contracts between the HIC and the nominated company in some cases—and liabilities to Medibank Private by ministerial declaration are specifically covered in the bill. Gazettal of any related determinations and a number of other determinations necessary to effect separation will ensure the transparency of transactions.

Staff affected by the transfer will be treated fairly. Where an employee is transferred under these provisions, their terms and conditions of employment and other rights and entitlements defined in the bill, have been preserved. The bill does not, of course, prevent variations at a later date under any law, award, determination or agreement, but the interests of staff will be taken into account by the Government.

Transferred employees will not be,entitled to any termination payment by leaving HIC employment, but re-transfer provisions will give considerable flexibility for staff transfers back to the HIC for a period of twelve months from the date on which the Commonwealth assumes ownership of the Medibank Private company.

Minor provisions in the bill include stamp duty exemption for designated matters necessary to carry out the separation, the capacity to transfer pending legal proceedings to the new company where appropriate. the transfer of records in accordance with the Archives Act 1983, provision for the company not to be taken legally as an agency of the Commonwealth, for the Minister to be represented at corporations law meetings by the Chairman or the Secretary, and delegations.

The bill also permits any complaints or investigations under the Ombudsman Act 1976 or the Privacy Act 1988, and requests under the Freedom of Information Act 1982, which may have been or have been made prior to the Medibank Private fund-transfer day, and which relate to Medibank Private, to be completed.

In order to meet the requirement for Medibank Private to operate on an equal footing with its competitors, these enactments will not apply to Medibank Private thereafter, other than in this transitional sense. The company will, however, continue to operate within the spirit of these regimes (as it does today where the Medibank Private business is not prescribed under these enactments). Medibank Private will, like its competitors, remain subject to the complaints investigations powers of the Private Health Insurance Complaints Commissioner.
The bill also makes a number of consequential changes to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, other acts. and the Health Insurance Commission Regulations.

The Government stresses that the provision of Medicare services will be maintained as a core HIC function, and the HIC will be expected to continue to strive for excellence in delivering quality claims and related services to the public. Other existing government programmes functions, including the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, will also continue to be performed by the HIC.

Additionally, the bill also recognises a widening role for the HIC in the delivery of health payments services and information to support health sector initiatives. The HIC may, in future, provide health information and payments support services to State governments as well as to the Commonwealth. For this reason, the bill permits consultation with the States and Territories as to their possible representation on the HIC board.
Other minor corporate governance changes and transitional arrangements are also made by the bill.
