TITLE.XREF: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (MALE TOTAL AVERAGE WEEKLY EARNINGS BENCHMARK) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 September, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I received some feedback that it was a very informative and interesting contribution that I was making yesterday on the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Male Total Average Weekly Earnings Benchmark) Bill 1997 .
—Very profound.
—It was profound, Senator Woodley. I thank you for that. I do appreciate the accolades that I have received for the first part of this particular speech.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I was making was that, on the one hand, we had the coalition's pre-election policy commitments and even post-election commitments with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) saying on radio 2GB in Sydney on 19 April last year:
Now we are not going to muck around with the levels of pensions or their automatic indexation.

Yet, on the other hand, it was the same Prime Minister, along with the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey), who on 16 April 1996 actually requested that the National Commission of Audit investigate and consider the issue of benchmarking the level of the aged pension against 25 per cent of average weekly earnings—not of male total average weekly earnings but of average weekly earnings. In particular, they asked the National Commission of Audit to investigate the appropriateness of the current benchmark being expressed in terms of average weekly earnings for males.

You see, mucking around with the pension benchmark would have a devastating impact on pensioners. The NCA report recommended changing the benchmark for male total average weekly earnings to a different measure of weekly earnings. The options presented were to make savings by measuring weekly earnings by all persons instead of males, or median instead of average weekly earnings. If the government were to break its commitment and follow the advice of the National Commission of Audit, it would result in a reduction in payments to pensioners who would lose around $15 a week if the median weekly earnings benchmark were used or, even more, around $27 a week if the all persons average weekly earnings benchmark were used.

This recommendation of the National Commission of Audit obviously caused enormous concern in the Australian community. I acknowledge—I try to be generous to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman—that the minister was quick to back away from the National Commission of Audit's findings. She put out a press release which stated:
The Government has ruled out fixing pensions by any different formula. The Government maintains its commitment to pensions being determined at 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings.

However, it is the view of the opposition and it is certainly now the view of the community more broadly that the commitments that this government gives or that any of the ministers of the government give are worth very little. Look at the way the government abolished the Commonwealth dental health scheme—that was another commitment that the government had given earlier on.

It was my view that, after the referral to the National Commission of Audit, we just could not trust Mr Howard or Senator Newman on this particular issue. If the recommendation of the National Commission of Audit were to be accepted by the government, it would effectively take millions and millions of dollars out of the pockets of pensioners. Put simply: I do not trust Mr Howard; I do not trust Senator Newman; and I certainly do not trust the Howard government.

We need to ensure that the current benchmark that Labor has been committed to, literally for generations, is secure—secure from the government's lack of commitment to pensioners and secure from the government's penchant for breaking its election commitments. This is the government that just does not appear to be able to uphold the promises that it has made. The way that we in the Labor Party saw fit to ensure that this benchmark was secure was to introduce benefits to the legislation I was speaking about yesterday—the Social Security (Budget and Other Measures Bill) 1996.

We have to ask ourselves: if the government were really committed to maintaining the benchmark and enshrining it in legislation, why have they given it an expiry date? Why have they whacked a five‐year sunset clause into this bill? The answer is that, really, they are not committed. We will not accept this sunset clause. We will not accept Mr Howard's and Senator Newman's escape clause in this legislation.

Not only have they imposed an expiry date in the bill but they have also given this legislation very narrow parameters. The legislation deals only with pensions, leaving allowances vulnerable to the government's slash and burn policies. Under Labor we ensured that the benchmark increases flowed on to most allowances. This government's legislation does not ensure that the benchmark increases will flow on to hundreds of thousands of people on allowances, breaking the longstanding nexus between pensions and allowances, further widening the gap between rates of payment.

Another flaw in the government's legislation is that the adjustment is retrospective. That is, when pensions are adjusted each March and September they will be aligned with 25 per cent of the latest available estimate for average weekly earnings. Those estimates will, by that time, be nearly six months old. This means that, with average earnings growing by 3½ to four per cent a year and the CPI at about 1¾ per cent, at no time will the pension actually be at 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. At each indexation point the pension will be around 24.6 per cent of male total average weekly earnings, declining over the next six months. In contrast, Labor kept the pension above 25 per cent of average weekly earnings at all times. As I said, it was about 25.3 per cent at the time Labor left office—a point that Senator Neal made most persuasively in her speech. This difference is significant; it is equivalent to $4 per week for a single pensioner.

We certainly support this legislation enshrining the benchmarking of pension rates at at least 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings. It is actually our initiative. It is the initiative of the opposition. But we distance ourselves completely from the government's underhand approach to dealing with this by placing a sunset clause on the legislation and severing the link between pensions and allowances. Senator Neal will be moving amendments at a later stage to attempt to resolve those issues.
I commend to the Senate the opposition's approach on this legislation and look forward to the Senate supporting the initiatives that Senator Neal will be progressing on our behalf.

In relation to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal annual report 1996‐97, I think it would be useful to indicate that it probably makes a fairly telling pigeon pair with the Ombudsman's report of 1996‐97, which we did not get a chance to speak to in this chamber.

The reason it is fairly important in conjunction with that report is that both give a very worrying picture of increased concerns and complaints within the community about the level of service they are receiving. We found out from the Ombudsman's report that there is a growing number of people who are not getting access to good advice.

There were circumstances where people were entitled to get some assistance with meeting the cost of luxuries—like daily bread on their table, and so on—and there had been mistakes in advice given to them. There was no accountability and no responsibility taken by the departments for providing proper advice, and people were often penalised for being given bad advice in the first place.

We find out from the Social Security Appeals Tribunal annual report that the number of lodgments of new applications for review is at an all‐time high of 13,817. This is 12.9 per cent up on the previous year, and 46.3 per cent up over a period of two years. When the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) comes into this chamber and we hear her talking about the tens of thousands of people who have been thrown off social security—the indication being that those people were cheats—you can only look at figures like 13,817 and wonder how many people are there in the community who actually know that they can access the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.

What kind of information is available to those people who receive their letters—or who sometimes do not receive their letters because they have been sent to the wrong address and they get their social security cut off anyway—and find that they have no means of support, who do not know that they have rights to appeal and who do not know that there is something they can do if they have no means of surviving?

We all know, and there is clear evidence, that agencies out in the community—the church groups and so on—are desperately short of funds to try to make up emergency care for those people upon whom the system is turning its back. The indications are that appeals against the Department of Social Security decisions fell as a proportion of total appeals but that they rose by 10.3 per cent in numerical terms, and that most of the growth concerned decisions about family payment allowance. We must remember that this was a centre point of the government's election proposals, but it seems that it is not working very well.

It also seems that quite a large number of people who are putting in their appeals are actually succeeding. It would seem to give the lie to the indication that the Minister for Social Security would tend to give that the figures for those people who have been thrown off social security indicate that there are that many cheats in society. Unfortunately, when they are people on social security benefits, we do not give them the benefit of the doubt as we might perhaps do for people in the government who have problems with their travel claims. We do not give them the benefit of the doubt and we do not say, `Innocent until proven guilty.' What we say, what the minister is saying and what the department is now saying is, `Guilty until proven innocent.'

Some people—obviously, a growing number of people—are trying to find out where they can possibly go to right some of the wrongs that may have been perpetuated against them. I should think that 13,817 new applications is probably the tip of the iceberg. It is a disgraceful indictment on the current way that discretion has presumably been removed from officers of various departments in terms of acting professionally and giving people the benefit of the doubt and finding out whether they are in the wrong rather than being officious enough to take people off their only means for support for such things as maybe not turning up for an interview they did not know they were supposed to be at or a response to a letter which was sent to an address where they were no longer living. It might be a case where there were rules that people were badly advised. Both the Ombudsman's report and the annual report of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal seem to indicate that there is a growing number of people who are constantly falling between the gaps.

Maybe the next response from the government will further remove funding from the Ombudsman and the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. Maybe if you take away the fund ing, these people might go away and you do not even have to hear about it in the parliament. That is the frightening scenario that I see in the future. (Time expired)

Quick, cheap, efficient and fair review is essential for the proper operation of government. I rise to speak to the protocol with the International Atomic Energy Agency, done at Vienna on 23 September 1997. With that is the national interest analysis in relation to that treaty. I am rising because there are a number of issues involved with this treaty and Australia's response to it. It is a very complex issue.

One of the ongoing problems in relation to the International Atomic Energy Agency is that it is and continues to have a dual function—that is, it is an agency which has the function of providing safeguards but it is also an agency whose function is to promote the use of nuclear fuel. Basically, it is the seller and the policeman at the same time. There have been concerns about that for many years, and that does not seem to be changing.

There is a concern in Australia that the money Australia puts into our own nuclear safeguards office is perhaps insufficient for the level of radiation related industry in Australia. I applaud and welcome any increased safeguards that are involved with this agreement. I suppose there are a few people who would not applaud any increases in safeguards.

I wonder, though, whether this is real effectiveness or whether it is paper effective ness. A short while ago in the Senate, I rose to speak to the Australian Safeguard Office report on Lucas Heights and realised that after two lots of three months there were still major problems in the operation there, most of which we did not see because it did not come out in the agenda. But Australia still gets ticks on the paper internationally for being seen to operate an effective safeguard regime.

Australia is active in the international arena in negotiations on such things as international atomic energy agreements. However, one wonders whether this is being used as an excuse for Australia to be involved in putting together a new reactor—if Australia needs it at all. Of course, there is a whole different issue about whether or not the science is anything more than mediocre, whether or not the net $2.5 million cost involved with ANSTO and Lucas Heights has been in any way rewarded to the Australian community and whether or not there are alternative ways, for instance, for accessing radioisotopes for medical purposes. The government has not seen fit to address those issues in any full way, except that the minister selectively quoted from a four year old Internet article to suggest that this is what the government has looked at in the last few years to find alternative methods of medical isotopes. Of course, that is not good enough.

Here we have Australia vying, if you like, for a continued seat on international negotiations. The cost has been and will continue to be very expensive. The cost of being on that seat could end up being the cost of decommissioning our current reactor—it has been acknowledged as having problems and needing to be shut down over time—the cost of dealing with the waste forever, in any realistic sense, and also the cost of potentially putting together a new reactor in the future and then dealing with the waste and the other problems associated with that.

It remains to be seen that the paper achievements with such protocols will bear fruit. Signing the protocol should not be seen as Australia's response to greenhouse gas reductions. It is far from that. There are many other environmental and health problems associated with nuclear energy. I think it is a very expensive seat that Australia has had on the international table, and in the future we will have to think twice about whether spending $2.5 billion gives us any credibility on the international arena if at the same time we are continuing to promote the sale of uranium for other people's proliferation. I seek leave to continue my remarks on this report at a later date.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter that I wish to raise on the adjournment debate tonight is the affiliation, so‐called, of the Armidale campus of the University of New England with the National Union of Students. My attention was drawn to this matter by an article in the Australian on 17 September, in which the President of the National Union of Students, Mr John Carey, boasted about this affiliation and the rise of support for the National Union of Students. He gratuitously pointed out that this was due to the personal style and comments of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, which had the effect of raising the NUS's profile and giving the organisation credibility. However, this evening I want to point out to the Senate that credibility is something that the National Union of Students does not enjoy in any shape or form.

To enable a referendum on affiliation to the National Union of Students to occur, a petition signed by at least 300 students is required. The student association, being aware that they would be unlikely to get 300 stu dents to sign such a petition, had a free barbecue for the day and signed up people as they came along for the barbecue—an old tactic employed by the left wing on student unions for ever and a day, it would seem. I know it occurred in my day, and I used to fight vociferously against it. Unfortunately, it would appear that 20 years later not much has changed.

We have this petition of allegedly 300 students. The thing we have not been able to completely get a grasp on is how many of those signatories were in fact valid students. We do know that 390 signatures appeared on the petition, but the chief executive officer knocked out at least 75. We are not told whether he knocked out more to undermine that threshold of 300 signatures. Suffice it to say that that first apparent rort was then allowed to go to a referendum of the student body.

Those at the Armidale campus of the University of New England would be aware that there are many internal students, but even more external students. Those students who study on campus voted overwhelmingly against affiliation. However, external students voted overwhelmingly in favour of affiliation. You have to ask the question: what could be the possible difference? There is a very clear difference between the strategies that were employed. The students on campus were provided with a no case. Individual students organised to convince their fellow students on campus that it was not a good idea to join the National Union of Students, and that was overwhelmingly supported by their fellow students.

Why did the external students happen to have a different point of view? It is instructive to learn that in 1995 a similar affiliation attempt was defeated by the student body. Do you know the big mistake the students' association made? They sent out a yes case and a no case to the external students with their postal ballot. What a foolish thing to do; to send out both sides of the argument with a postal ballot!

Indeed, this is exposed in the minutes of the University of New England Armidale Students' Association special council meeting held on 10 August 1997 at 8.00 p.m. by way of a teleconference. Tanya Barber and Joshua Walmsley moved a particular motion and certain comments were noted in the minutes. It is also instructive to note that Tanya Barber is a paid employee of the Australian Workers Union whilst also being on the student union association. I have no problem with that, but listen to the tricks that she gets up to. The minutes of that special council meeting state:

Tanya Barber outlined the experience of the 1995 NUS affiliation referendum, in which both a `Yes' and a `No' case were included with the ballot papers, and misinformation and confusion of the students with incorrect information about the affiliation had resulted.
The poor little dears! The students could not really make a decision for themselves when they were confronted with a yes and a no case. What did they decide? The minutes further state:
The meeting felt that it was not the role of the ASA to distribute misleading information—
in other words, the no case—
to the students, and that including an information sheet would be more appropriate.

Let me refer to this NUS information sheet. It has NUS letterhead on it. It has the logo on it and it tells us: `NUS uncovered. Yes to NUS. NUS representing over 500,000 students'. That was the information sheet. Of course, it was a biased sheet in favour of the yes campaign. These people who promote student democracy and compulsory student unionism get their power and their manipulation by rorting the system, as I have just exposed.

The external students were only given the yes case under the guise of an information sheet and were denied their democratic right to hear the no case. I understand that they played the same game on campus when students turned up to a ballot box to vote. The ballot papers were handed out with this so-called information sheet, and the no case was not allowed to be handed out with the ballot paper. Despite that, on campus, where students were able to read the no case for themselves, they overwhelmingly rejected the National Union of Students.

BREAK.PARA: Where is the credibility of this National Union of Students that Mr Carey tries to claim and, undoubtedly, misled the Australian into printing? What this campaign shows is that the NUS supporters were so scared of the success of the no case—and with good reason, because when the no case was presented to the students they overwhelmingly rejected NUS—they would not allow the other point of view to be put. As a result of that, they won the day.

If the university council does not intervene in this issue, they will have absolutely and utterly abrogated their responsibilities as the governing university council, which is the body that enforces compulsory student unionism on this campus. If students do not join the union, they are denied their results. They are denied the right to study and an academic career. All the hot air that we have heard from people on the other side of the chamber about the right of people to gain a tertiary education is overlooked and forgotten when it comes to the question of compulsory student unionism, which is unfortunately a blot on our society and a requirement if you want a tertiary education.

Having highlighted those facts, the point that I wish to make is that a paid official of the Australian Workers Union was involved in this scam at the University of New England. The supporters of the National Union of Students were involved in this scam to win by a margin of about 100 votes. Why students should be forced to pay a compulsory levy to such an organisation is beyond me. Why the Australian Workers Union allows somebody to remain in their employ whilst their officials get up to the behaviour that I have just outlined in relation to Tanya Barber is beyond me.

Possibly what is happening is that the big grown‐up trade union is teaching the little student unionists how to behave when they grow up and become trade unionists and then get catapulted into the federal parliament through their union affiliations. It creates a complete culture of rorting the democratic process. I call on the university council of the University of New England to investigate and invalidate this referendum. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak about a ceremony I attended last Sunday, 28 September—the National Day of Remembrance for those who have lost their lives to drugs, I was invited to attend this ceremony which was held at the Gold Coast in Queensland. It was a beautiful ceremony, attended by family and friends of loved ones and, I must admit, I was very pleased and honoured to be included. The reason I was there was twofold: one, because I wanted to be there; and, two, because I was asked to dedicate a newly planted tree, a bauhinia alba.

SPEECH.PARA: This tree symbolises the lives of those who have died from drug use. In spring the tree is covered with leaves and beautiful blossoms, symbolising the beautiful and special person we remember so well. In winter the tree stands bare revealing thorny branches, signifying how the person is thought of, through ignorance and misunderstanding, by many in our community. This tree will grow in a place of beauty near the sea and will provide testimony to families who have lost loved ones that they have support from others in the community. The presence of the tree will also serve as a reminder to the community that those who have died have a right to be remembered with love and dignity.

Tonight I want to pay tribute to those people who helped make this service possible. The ceremony was organised by the Family and Friends for Drug Law Reform. The Master of Ceremonies was Rohan Wenn, who conducted the proceedings with dignity and compassion. Speeches were made by parents Pat Assheton and David Cuthbert. Also a message was sent by the Mayor of the Gold Coast City Council, Gary Baildon, who could not be there. Officiating in his place was Councillor Lex Bell, about whom I will speak later. The site was blessed by Father Joseph Thottankara. As I have said, I was extremely honoured to be asked to participate in this ceremony and, as you can imagine, Madam Acting Deputy President, it was an extremely emotional occasion.

I would also like to pay tribute to a band called Fire Sign, who performed music and songs containing messages of the dangers of drugs. They were a very young band, and they were excellent. I would also like to pay tribute to a young woman by the name of Jamie Lee Wilson. She sang a song called Tears of Ice, written by a mother who had lost her son to drugs, and also a song she had written herself in memory of her dear friend Lisa, who also had lost her life to drugs.

I particularly want to place on record my congratulations to the Gold Coast City Council who have thrown their support behind those of us in this country who believe in drug law reform. By doing so, they have proved to be not only progressive but also exceptionally aware of what is a growing problem not only on the Gold Coast but also in our community at large throughout Australia. They have also shown themselves to be a council that is not afraid of trying to do something about this problem.

The Gold Coast City Council placed a monument and plaque in a small park on the very busy Esplanade at Surfers Paradise, overlooking the ocean. This plaque was unveiled by former Mayor, Councillor Lex Bell. Councillor Bell said that this place would become a `focal point for those who grieve'. This, of course, is what will happen. But for some of us, like me, whose son's ashes were scattered at sea, it will indeed become a special place. I would like to thank those of the council for that.

The ceremony gave those of us who attended a chance to offer each other support and understanding, and to demonstrate that families are not alone in their struggle to come to terms with drug related deaths. When a person dies from drug problems, it is the families who are left to mourn and suffer. Sunday's ceremony, with its emphasis on new life, showed those families and friends present that there is support, sympathy and solidarity both within this assembly and in the general community.

This gathering must also be an example to those in authority that the present treatments and programs are not working. Each year there are over 500 opiate related deaths. This is grossly unsatisfactory in our community. I urge all governments to have a profound look at the tragedy each one of these deaths causes, let alone in numbers of such magnitude—and, more importantly, to look at the reasons why.

As I said on the day, I hope that this ceremony and those held in the future will help the community realise the plight of families who have lost loved ones, and will be able to break down traditional stereotypes and prejudices that have long been associated with drug use. An educated community is a caring and compassionate community, and I hope that this and other ceremonies throughout the country will help to take us a further step towards this goal.

I once again applaud the Gold Coast City Council for their support and, before I finish, I would like to publicly apologise to my friend Councillor Lex Bell. On the day I was so concerned about getting through my dedication speech without crying that I quite forgot my manners and did not acknowledge Councillor Bell. For that I apologise—and, of course, I did not achieve my aim.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to speak on a document called Planning to succeed in child care , which has been produced by the Department of Health and Family Services and which was recently delivered to my electorate office. I am sure fellow senators will agree that it is an impressive looking document, produced by the department under an impressive sounding strategy called the national child-care information strategy. The document contains 22 sections, 50 pages of information for current and prospective child-care providers. In introducing the kit, the current Minister for Family Services, Mrs Moylan, said:

SPEECH.PARA: It outlines a national planning strategy which builds on existing partnerships with state and local governments and improves the quality of information available to existing and potential investors in child care.
We read of the minister's responsibility to provide support for families who need access to quality care and of partnerships between government and the child‐care industry.

BREAK.PARA: We even read in this document:
. . . achieving quality outcomes for children using long day care centres is underpinned by a comprehensive quality improvement and accreditation system.

There is silence at the moment from the opposite benches, but I recall the period some two years ago when accreditation was very much an issue dear to the hearts of some coalition senators. If I recall correctly, Senator McGauran had particular concerns about Christmas carols. Those opposite are silent now.

As I have already said, this impressive package contains 22 sections, 50 pages detailing all sorts of information for potential child‐care providers. However, what the minister does not say in her foreword is that the entire document is based on legislative changes proposed by the government in the Child Care Payments Bill 1997 that is not even before the Senate yet. The bill has been referred to the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee with a report back date of 27 October, but the document is out there in the community. The legislation proposes to put in place administrative changes to operate from 1 January 1998. I will get to that point later, because it really is putting the cart before the horse.

Here we have a government that has made cuts to child care of over $800 million in the last two budgets, increasing the cost of child care and encouraging the growth of informal care, yet it can squander taxpayers' money with the production of this type of propaganda that is not even current—again, putting the cart before the horse. If we look at section six of the package, it starts off with this disclaimer:
Full details of the new arrangements outlined here will be contained in legislation which is expected to be effective from 1 January 1998, but has not yet been passed by parliament.
Well, that is a half truth. The bill has not even been introduced into the Senate at this stage.

Let us look more clearly at section six, which is entitled `Targeting areas of need'. First, we start with the disclaimer. Then we have an introduction, a background section and a section entitled `Longer term outlook'. The background section introduces an issue very dear to me—child-care planning. Child‐care planning is very important in the area in which I reside because it has the largest number of children under the age of five in Australia. This background section states:
Commonwealth funding for new community sponsored long day care centres, family day care and outside school hours care services is—
as we all know—
limited to the amounts provided through the budget.

Whilst the government might claim it has made some changes which address some issues of equity in relation to child-care services, it has not redirected that money into the industry; it has just cut services. It further states what we all know: New places are established in the high need areas identified through a needs based planning process.
The government has been talking about this process for some time. That is why I was particularly keen to have a look at this document to see what was part of the plan.

Let us look at the high need areas identified through a needs based planning process. This is mentioned in the section entitled `Longer term outlook'. There is a list of the government's objectives in establishing a new national planning system. They include: equity for families; a focus on meeting gaps; targeting of assistance to families; and certainty for parents. There are the strategies to encourage new services to areas of greatest need: providing information, advertising demand and supply information, and influencing new investors to locate in areas of need.

Then we finally get to the point that I might have been looking for under the heading `Main elements of the new planning system'. This point talks about better supply and demand information and then states that an Australia‐wide assessment of areas of need for child care should be undertaken by October 1997. I hope that assessment is undertaken by October 1997 and that something will come out of a document such as this, which will actually tell the industry what they want to do and what investments they want to make for 1998 and 1999. But it is not leaving the industry with much time.

This document, Planning to succeed in child care, is certainly not providing the industry with the information that they need. It says that information on high needs areas will be made available through this kit—but the kit is already out there—and through an Internet site. Within the limits, and they seem to be fairly comprehensive limits, operators will only be approved to receive Commonwealth child-care assistance if they are established in these identified areas of need. New places established in areas other than those identified—which have not yet been identified—will not attract Commonwealth child-care assistance during 1998 and 1999.

Here is this government's answer to providing timely information to potential child‐care providers—Planning to succeed in child care. This document, every page of which is labelled `effective at 29 August 1997', talks about planning and targeting new services for 1998 and 1999 in areas of high need, such as where I live.

But what is the reality? The reality is that much of this document is based on legislation which may not have passed the Senate by the time many of its proposed changes are due to commence. The reality is that the potential investors in new child-care places for 1998—next year—have no idea of where the high needs areas are. Thus, they have no idea which areas will have access to Commonwealth child-care assistance. The reality is that this document represents something besides being a waste of taxpayers' money; it masquerades as proof of government support for the child-care industry.

The government is trying to say it is doing something when there is nothing there. It is a Trojan horse. The reality of the situation is a government that has introduced changes which have seen families removing their children from centres—73 per cent of whom cite increased fees as their reasons for leaving—and a government that is taking child care back to the days of low standard informal care. The National Association of Community Based Children's Services says that 67 per cent of families leaving centres are now using informal care. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to refer to Rabelais , which is a student newspaper published monthly by La Trobe University. The publisher is the students' association of that particular university. An article that Rabelais published entitled `The art of shoplifting' has, to the shock of the Australian Democrats and many others in the community, brought extensive legal proceedings against the editors. Tonight I want to talk about this issue and point out the need to re‐evaluate and re-examine the relevant laws in this case.

SPEECH.PARA: The laws involved in this case are both state and territory laws which have been adopted from the Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 from the act as it was amended in 1989. The relevant words in those laws are that any publication will be refused classification if it `instructs in matters of crime or violence'. In Victoria, any material that is deemed objectionable material cannot be published. So material, therefore, that is refused classification is objectionable material and its publication can lead to a penalty.

Following an approach by the Retail Traders Association of Victoria, the Chief Censor refused classification to this La Trobe publication of the article `The art of shoplifting' on the basis that the publication `instructed in methods of shoplifting and associated fraud'—an exact quote from the Chief Censor. This decision was confirmed by the Classification Board and reasons were provided on 26 July 1996. That decision has been subject to review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.

The heart of this matter is the national classification code which sets out the publications which are to be refused classification. These are publications which `promote, incite or instruct in matters of crime and violence'. The Rabelais article was considered by the board to instruct in matters of crime because it was a step‐by‐step guide to shoplifting. So the board decided that it had a political flavour but that it did not have any indicators of satire or tongue in cheek and that it therefore did not fulfil those particular criteria. It was deemed to have a political flavour and to be instructing people how to commit shoplifting crimes.

The board recognised the nature of the publication and its audience—the student audience, which is, presumably, a reasonably educated audience willing to take into account a variety of factors and the context in which this publication was made available—but concluded that the critical issue was the intent to instruct in crime. This decision has now been upheld by the Federal Court and will be subject to further review by the full Federal Court in the near future.

The concern I have tonight is that this case has identified a clear failing in our laws, and it is now the place for parliament to fix that particular failing. I make no assessment of the legal arguments in this case, on the basis that the technical legal issues are a distraction from the issue which the parliament must decide upon—and that is our need to enable open and accessible debate.

The Rabelais case is a good example of the random application of the particular law involved. For example, if the Retail Traders Association of Victoria had not raised the matter this publication would have joined any number of other publications that have not fallen foul of this law—maybe they would have but they have never even been considered as possible contenders. That is, they have never been referred for or highlighted as containing deemed objectionable material.

If we were to examine them, the range of publications and other materials in our community that could actually fall foul of the particular legislation is incredible, for example, union leaflets calling on workers to strike. What about a boxing manual, which clearly instructs people how to box and, presumably, to inflict damage on others? A range of other materials could be deemed objectionable or, in particular, instructing or inciting crime.

BREAK.PARA: According to a recent article by Australian lawyer Geoffrey Dutton in September 1996, the article `The art of shoplifting' reminded him of his student days when hippies would wrap a jacket around a book that stated, `steal this book'. Geoffrey Dutton actually points to examples of films and books that Australia has seen fit to censor in the past. I can name a number of examples, including Frankenstein because of its horror component, Of Mice and Men because of its sex and violence components—funny that that was lost on me when I studied the book—and The Challenge for its kidnapping references. These are concrete examples of materials that our laws should not exclude but which, under the laws in their present form, would be excluded.

If people really wanted to instruct themselves in matters of crime or violence, they would not really need to go to the student papers—they need look only as far as last night's television programs. At 7.30 p.m. Channel 7 showed Australia's Most Wanted, which involves the re‐enactment of actual crimes. They could then switch over to Channel 9 at about 8.30 and watch Murder Call in which what at first appears to be a suicide unravels to reveal a murder case. To finish off that diet of viewing, they could stay on Channel 9 for Diagnosis: Murder in which, presumably, they could watch the machinations of at least one, if not several, murders taking place.

Or, for example, if someone wanted to pursue the matter of shoplifting and be instructed in how to commit that crime, perhaps on a larger scale, they could rent the video of an English movie called Shopping, which was released a few years ago. It was not actually banned in this country but it did detail—and, you could argue, potentially instructed people in—ram raids. Clearly, that would fall foul of this particular piece of legislation. However, the most blatant example, and perhaps an obvious one, of a publication that instructs in stealing is Oliver Twist, the Charles Dickens classic, which talks about instructing Oliver in pick‐pocketing—`pick a pocket or two'. What if that were to be removed under these guidelines?

I do not mean to look at ludicrous or perhaps somewhat farcical or extreme examples because the point is that the ones I have cited are not. Yet, under the laws and under the classification codes as they are currently constructed, if these particular publications, articles, videos or television programs were referred to a board, potentially they could be banned on the basis of being objectionable material and penalties, perhaps even gaol sentences, could be incurred.

The solution to this matter is a reconsideration of the particular provision by the law‐makers, and in Australia that would involve a number of states and territories and, of course, the federal parliament. I think we want to retain the diversity of materials that form our entertainment and our education in this country, but we must have a law that cannot be arbitrarily applied, and its wording must be clear not only to avoid confusion but also to ensure that we protect our community and that we treasure and protect the very freedoms we have in this country when it comes to civil liberties, the press and speech.
